newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: UBS announces restructuring, expects loss.
newsitem.headline: UBS announces restructuring, expects loss.

text.p: Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS), the nation's largest bank, on Tuesday announced a restructuring plan for its domestic operations which will result in a special three-billion Swiss franc ($2.3 billion) charge and a group loss for 1996.

UBS said it expected the group net loss to amount to about half a billion francs. The three-billion-franc charge was being taken to cover the future development of credit risk in its domestic portfolio and the measures would result in a reduction of the group's equity capital.
It said a provision of 120 million francs would also be taken to cover restructuring costs in the group's Region Switzerland.

"After the measures have been implemented, group equity will amount to 21.5 billion Swiss francs at the end of this year, compared with 23 billion at the end of 1995," UBS chief executive Mathis Cabiallavetta said in the text of a speech prepared for a news conference.
The restructuring calls for the bank to reduce the number of so-called domestic economic areas to eight from the current 31.
It said direct rationalisation effects would be generated in particular by the concentration of support functions at only eight locations and a reduction in staff departments.
UBS also anticipates the elimination of some 800 domestic jobs as a result of the restructuring.
As a result of the restructuring, UBS said it expected incremental earnings of 200 million francs a year from 1998 onwards.

In addition, UBS said that as a result of the planned measures, Standard & Poor's had put the group on its Credit Watch List. However, Moody's Investor Service and IBCA, the European credit rating agency, have maintained their long-term AAA ratings on the groups.
However, IBCA said it downgraded its individual rating on UBS to A/B from A, while maintaining its other ratings.
UBS further stated that its 1996 dividend would be unchanged despite the loss.
